text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Wednesday's Pakistani newspapers:
DAWN
- The government has decided to reinvite bids for the privatisation of United Bank Ltd.
- The government has extended the period for the duty-free import of cotton.
- Fund management market of roughly six to seven billion rupees may shrink as the State (central) Bank of Pakistan is tightening control to check faulty fund management accounts.
- Government officials say paddy and cotton crop cultivated on 150,000 acres have been washed away in recent floods.
- Pakistan has expressed its concern over the cruise missile strikes by the U.S. against selected air defence targets inside Iraq.
- Opposition leader Nawaz Sharif has failed to give a date for a march on Islamabad.
- Pharmaceutical companies have raised drug prices by over 32 percent.
- Christians observed a day-long hunger strike to express their solidarity with Kashmiris fighting for self-determination.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- The government plans to establish raw material banks in industrial cities to ensure ready availability of raw materials.
- Textile mills are ready to buy Pakistani cotton at international prices if domestic consumers are given priority before going for exports.
FINANCIAL POST

- The $200 million off-shore securitisation fund for Pakistan Telecommunication Company Ltd receivables, being set up jointly by ABN-AMRO and Citibank in the United States, is expected to be launched within a couple of weeks.
THE NEWS
- The management of Dhan Fibres have reported to the stock exchange that some fake shares of the company have been detected.
- The Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank has sanctioned $15 million for the National Refinery Ltd to finance crude oil purchases from Saudi Arabia.
- The Singapore-based company Promet will invest $130 million to develop a software technology park in Islamabad.
- The central executive committee of the ruling Pakistan People's Party urged the government to hold bye-elections if opposition members decide to resign from the assemblies.
-- Islamabad newsroom 9251-274757
